I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to Nepal for the Transport Project Preparatory Facility. 
 
2.  The facility will assist the government’s effort to ensure that critically important road and 
air transport projects are implemented efficiently by systematically advancing the preparatory 
activities. The facility will identify and prepare high-priority projects for potential funding by the 
government and/or by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) or other development partners in the 
country.  This  preparation  will  include  feasibility  studies,  safeguard  due  diligence,  detail 
engineering design, bidding documents, and procurement assistance for advance contracting (if 
appropriate). This will contribute significantly to (i) improving the implementation performance of 
the ensuing projects by reducing the period between project concept and loan approval and the 
commencement of improvement works, (ii) helping to achieve the intended outcomes efficiently, 
and (iii) realizing the projects’ impacts and benefits in a timely manner. The facility will also 
provide capacity development support to help establish an enabling environment, supporting the 
government’s goal of developing transport infrastructure under public–private partnership (PPP). 
The facility will prepare transport projects that will contribute to improving connectivity and 
accessibility throughout the country. The facility is also relevant to ADB’s sector strategy in 
support  of  the  government’s  goal  of  achieving  regionally  balanced  economic  growth  and 
reduced social inequalities. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Nepal is a landlocked Himalayan country bordered to the north by the People’s Republic 
of China, and to the south, east, and west by India. The country is commonly divided into three 
physiographic areas with dramatic differences in elevation: the mountains in the north, the hills 
in  the  middle,  and  the  Terai  (southern  lowland  plains)  bordering  India.  Because  of  its 
mountainous terrain and difficult weather conditions, roads and aviation are the major modes of 
transportation in the country. 
 
4.  Nepal’s road network is about 18,500 km long, comprising the 7,500 km strategic road 
network (SRN) of national and feeder roads connecting district headquarters, and the 11,000 
km local and rural roads network. The total road network density is comparatively low, at about 
14 km per 100 square kilometer and 0.71 km/1,000 people.1 Due to mountainous terrain in the 
north, more than 60% of the road network is concentrated in the Terai. In the remote hill and 
mountainous districts, the poor condition and low density of roads hampers the delivery of social 
services and access to shops, markets, schools, and hospitals.  
 
5.  Civil  aviation  in  Nepal  plays  a  vital  role  in  linking  the  remote  areas  in  hilly  and 
mountainous parts of the country that are otherwise inaccessible by road, and is crucial to the 
growth of trade and tourism in the country. Nepal has 47 airports, comprising one international 
airport (Tribhuvan International Airport [TIA] in Kathmandu), four regional airports (Bhairawa, 
Biratnagar, Nepalgunj, and Pokhara), and 42 small domestic airports and short take-off and 
landing strips. The volume of air traffic in terms of air passengers has increased considerably 
(1990—2010), with growth rates varying from 7% to more than 17% per annum.  
                                                 
1  By comparison, regional figures in terms of km/1,000 people are Bhutan 6.5, Sri Lanka 4.7, India 3.0, Bangladesh 
1.9, and Pakistan 1.7.

2 
6.  The importance of the transport sector has been recognized and highlighted in several 
key  national  plans  and  strategies,  including  the  government’s  Three  Year  Interim  Plan 
(FY2007/08–FY2009/10).2 It emphasizes the role of the road and air transport subsectors in 
improving accessibility, which is one of the defining development issues in the country—be it 
access to opportunity, enterprise, markets, or services. Poor rural access and high external and 
domestic  transport  costs  are  major  obstacles  to  achieving  one  of  the  government’s  major 
development goals—broad-based economic growth. 
 
7.  For the road subsector, the Department of Roads (DOR) under the Ministry of Physical 
Planning and Works (MPPW) is in the process of implementing the 10-year Priority Investment 
Plan (PIP) 2007–2016.3 The PIP was prepared in 2007 with the World Bank’s assistance and 
presents  a  detailed  strategy  for  the  development  of  the  SRN  and  recommends  a  list  of 
interventions in the form of rehabilitation, upgrading, and new construction. The interventions 
are prioritized in terms of network connectivity, improved accessibility (including remote area 
access), and network strengthening. These, collectively, provide connectivity throughout the 
country by providing interregional connections and links to district headquarters, international 
borders, and key economic centers. The SRN is also an enabler of local and district access by 
allowing development of local road networks within each individual district and facilitating the 
provision of access to remote communities. The government, through the development of the 
SRN, aims to enhance national levels of social and economic integration, redress regional 
inequalities  and  imbalances,  and  reduce  levels  of  exclusion  in  the  remote  and  more 
disadvantaged  areas.  ADB’s  current  strategy  in  the  road  subsector  is  assisting  the 
government’s  effort  to  improve  and  expand  the  SRN  in  line  with  the  PIP,  including  the 
rehabilitation and upgrading of about 300 km under the ongoing Road Connectivity Sector 1 
Project.4 The PIP is targeted to improve, upgrade, and/or add about 4,500 km of roads and 
expand the total SRN to about 9,700 km by 2016. This is expected to raise accessibility, in 
terms of the percentage of the population that is within a 4-hour (or less) walk of paved roads in 
hill areas and a 2-hour (or less) walk in Terai areas, from 65% in 2007 to 85% by 2016. 
 
8.  For the air transport sector, the government has recognized the urgent need to improve 
safety and capacity in view of the rising traffic, which is forecasted to double by 2019.5 At the 
country's  only  international  airport  (TIA),  airside  facilities,  runways,  taxiways,  aprons,  and 
communication  navigation  surveillance  equipment  are  not  fully  compliant  with  international 
safety standards and recommended practices. The international terminal building is nearing its 
passenger  handling  capacity  and  the  domestic  terminal  building  is  operating  beyond  its 
capacity. Of the 42 domestic airports, only 27 are operational. Most of the short take-off and 
landing  strips  in  remote  areas  are  unpaved,  have  no  terminal  facilities,  and  lack  modern 
communication, navigation, and weather equipment. ADB’s recently approved Air Transport 
Capacity  Enhancement  Project  is  designed  to  address  priority  safety  and  capacity 
enhancements at TIA and three remote domestic airports—Lukla, Rara, and Simikot.6 In the

long term, however, the combined international and domestic passenger traffic volume at TIA is 
forecasted to reach 9.3 million passengers by 2028. To meet this demand, further capacity 
expansion  and  safety  enhancements  are  envisaged  at  TIA  and  the  domestic  airports  and 
airstrips, particularly in the remote locations with high tourism development potential. ADB’s 
assistance in the air transport subsector is supporting sustained improvements to and upgrading 
of the air transport system with emphasis on safety, capacity, and security, and enhancing the 
Civil  Aviation  Authority  of  Nepal’s  (CAAN’s)  institutional  capabilities  and  organizational 
effectiveness (footnote 6).  
 
9.  To  further  expand  necessary  investment  in  infrastructure,  the  government  has  also 
expressed a commitment to develop and implement transport infrastructure projects through 
public–private partnership. However, in both the road and air transport subsectors, the start-up 
activities have been limited and there is a lack of a clear sector strategy and road maps. The 
preparatory capacity is low and institutional arrangement for implementation is uncertain. To 
facilitate an enabling environment, there is a need to conduct sector diagnostics, clarify or 
develop  sector  road  maps,  and  provide  capacity  strengthening  for  preparation  and 
implementation. 
 
10.  The main objective of the facility is to help ensure that critically important road and air 
transport projects are implemented efficiently by reducing the implementation gap period that 
exists between project concept and loan approval and the commencement of improvement 
works. The facility will systematically advance the preparation of high-priority transport projects, 
including  feasibility  studies,  safeguard  due  diligence,  detail  engineering  design,  bidding 
documents, and procurement assistance for advance contracting, as appropriate. The targeted 
outcome is a reduced implementation gap for ADB-funded projects from a typical 27 months to 
6  months.  The  facility  is  expected  to  contribute  significantly  towards  improving  the 
implementation performance of ensuing transport projects in Nepal, helping to achieve the 
intended outcomes efficiently and realizing their impact and benefits in a timely manner. 
 
11.  At least two road transport projects and one air transport project will be prepared under 
the facility. The road transport component will prepare improvement projects for high-priority 
SRN sections of about 1,300 km, identified in the PIP. To enhance subregional connectivity, 
priorities will also include SRN links to subregional transport corridors identified under the South 
Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) Regional Multimodal Transport Study.7 
The air transport component will prepare capacity enhancement and safety improvements at 
TIA in Kathmandu and other regional airports, as well as the domestic airports serving remote 
areas that are otherwise inaccessible by road.  
 
12.  The facility will also provide capacity development support to help establish an enabling 
environment  for  preparing  and  implementing  PPP  projects  in  the  road  and  air  transport 
subsectors. This support will include  
(i)  for PPP sector diagnostics and sector maps: (a) reviewing the legal, regulatory, 
and  policy  frameworks;  (b)  assessing  institutional  structures;  (c)  conducting 
stakeholder consultation; and (d) clarifying the sector strategy and road map;  
(ii)  for  identifying  and  preparing  at  least  one  small-scale  pilot  PPP  project:  (a) 
assessing  and  selecting  PPP  options,  (b)  defining  procurement  and  bid 
evaluation processes, and (c) preparing bid packages; and  
(iii)  procurement assistance, as appropriate. 
                                                 
7  SAARC Secretariat. 2007. SAARC Regional Multimodal Transport Study. Kathmandu (prepared under: ADB. 2004. 
Technical Assistance for Promoting South Asian Regional Economic Cooperation. Manila [TA 6187-REG]).

4 
 
13.  A potential ensuing project will be eligible for preparation under the facility if it is (i) 
organizationally and technically feasible; (ii) prima facie economically and financially viable and 
sustainable;  (iii)  environmentally  and  socially  responsible;  (iv)  consistent  and  prepared  in 
accordance  with  the  government's  relevant  sector  strategy,  master  plans,  or  medium-term 
development plan; and (v) consistent with ADB's Nepal country partnership strategy.8 For the 
road  transport  subsector,  the  facility  will  primarily  prepare  improvements  for  priority  SRN 
sections identified in the PIP. However, other candidate roads could also be considered if 
worthy in terms of improving accessibility (especially for poor people in rural areas); contributing 
to reduced social exclusion; and enhancing connectivity to regional and economic centers, 
international borders, and district headquarters. For the air transport subsector, the facility will 
prepare improvement projects to enhance safety, capacity, and security in line with the Civil 
Aviation Sector Strategy and Infrastructure Development Plan,9 updated master plan for TIA,10 
and the National Air Transport Development Plan.11  
 
14.  The implementation of the facility will be phased in line with ADB’s pipeline projects. For 
instance, the preparation of about 900 km of SRN roads (subgroup 1) will start immediately to 
facilitate  the  processing  of  ADB-funded  transport  projects  according  to  the  Nepal  country 
operations business plan 2011–2013.12 Preparation for the remaining SRN roads (subgroup 2, 
about 400 km) will commence in about mid-2013 for potential transport projects to be funded 
during later years by ADB and/or other development partners. 
 
15.  The road and air transport projects prepared under the facility will contribute to improved 
connectivity and accessibility. The facility supports the strategic objective established in ADB's 
Nepal country partnership strategy 2010–2012: assisting the government to achieve regionally 
balanced economic growth and reduced social inequalities. The facility is included in the Nepal 
country operations business plan 2010–2013. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The impact will be enhanced transport connectivity. The immediate outcome will be 
improved efficiency in implementing road and air transport projects. 
 
C.  Outputs 
17.  The outputs are (i) feasibility studies and detail design of road and air transport projects, 
and (ii) capacity development support to the DOR and CAAN for preparing and implementing 
PPP projects.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
24.  For the follow-on loans and grants, the engineering design will be carried out based on 
site condition survey and investigation, and the proposed improvement works will be optimized 
for economy and construction efficiency in accordance with best international practice and 
applicable standards.  
 
25.  The technical due diligence will also consider climatic hazards and disaster proneness, 
and, to the extent possible, apply built-in measures to minimize the adverse impacts of these. 
For instance, in Nepal, the excessive rainfall during monsoons can make steep roadside slopes

7 
in the hill areas susceptible to landslides and inundate roads in the low plain areas. For the 
roads in the hill areas, bioengineering techniques will be considered (where appropriate) as 
supplement to protect and stabilize roadside slopes.14 For the roads in the low plain areas, 
conventional civil engineering measures will be assessed, including embankment height, design 
values of storm frequency and runoff, drainage, and other appropriate technologies. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
26.  For the follow-on loans and grants, economic and financial viability and sustainability will 
be  assessed.  The  economic  assessment  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects,  assessing  the  economic  life  of  the 
components and identifying the economic benefits of each investment component comparing 
the with-project and without-project situation.15 For revenue-generating loans and grants, the 
financial analysis will be carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Financial 
Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by ADB (2002), calculating the 
financial internal rate of return for the overall investment and establishing the financial viability 
by comparing the financial internal rate of return with the cost of capital, taking into account 
financial costs and benefits. 
 
C.  Governance 
27.  Policy and legal. The DOR, implementing agency for the road transport component, 
was  established  in  1961.  Under  the  MPPW,  the  DOR  is  responsible  for  developing  and 
maintaining the strategic road network comprising the national arterial roads and major feeder 
roads connecting to local and rural roads. The DOR’s mission is to contribute to achieving 
sustainable socioeconomic development by providing safe affordable public road infrastructure 
services through the building of a cost-effective, efficient, and reliable road network system. The 
DOR is headed by a director general who reports to the secretary of the MPPW.  
 
28.  The CAAN, the implementing agency for the air transport component, was established 
by the Civil Aviation Authority Act in 1996 as an autonomous state authority, supervised by the 
Ministry of Tourism and Civil Aviation. The CAAN is responsible for the administration of civil 
aviation in Nepal, regulating civil aviation and operating the national airports and air traffic and 
air  navigation  systems.  Legal  authority  for  the  government  to  regulate  civil  aviation  was 
established  in  1960  through  the  Civil  Aviation  Act  which,  although  amended  periodically, 
remains the fundamental enabling legislation for regulation of civil aviation in Nepal.  
 
29.  Institutional capacity. The DOR has a good track record of implementing ADB-funded 
projects, and its capacity is being further enhanced under ADB’s ongoing capacity development 
technical assistance, which includes training to carry out feasibility studies for road transport 
projects, and learning best practices in contract management and quality assurance systems 
(footnote 4). The CAAN’s performance in regulating civil aviation has ensured that a good safety 
record has been achieved for air transport operations in Nepal’s uniquely hazardous aviation 
environment, while the operation of the airport and air navigation system has generated a profit 
for  the  CAAN  since  2004.  ADB’s  recently  approved  Air  Transport  Capacity  Enhancement 
Project  will  assess  further  improvement  needs  and  will  implement  a  3-year  capacity

30.  Both the DOR (for the road component) and CAAN (for the air transport component) 
have sufficient capacity, past experience, and institutional strength to implement the facility. 
Also, during implementation, both the DOR and CAAN will be supported by consultant services 
for feasibility studies, detail design, bidding documents, and applicable social and environmental 
due diligence. 
 
31.  Financial management. Financial management assessment was carried out for the 
implementing agencies—the DOR (for the national road transport component) and the CAAN 
(for the air transport component). The DOR has prior and ongoing experience with implementing 
ADB-funded projects and has satisfactory capacity in terms of project financial accounting and 
knowledge of ADB disbursement procedures. Within the DOR’s Project Directorate, the project 
implementation  unit  for  the  road  transport  component,  there  will  be  a  dedicated  project 
accounting  and  finance  team  consisting  of  three  qualified  accountants:  a  chief  project 
accountant and two assistant accountants. 
 
32.  The CAAN operates with an adequate system of financial and management accounting, 
reporting, auditing, and internal controls. However, efficiency is weak due to inadequate staff 
resources  and  lack  of  a  computerized  information  system.  The  capacity  strengthening 
component of ADB’s recently approved Air Transport Capacity Enhancement Project will help 
address this by introducing a financial management information system consisting of accounting 
software,  networked  computers,  and  training  (footnote  6).  The  CAAN  will  assign  suitably 
qualified accountants (a chief project accountant and an assistant accountant) to the project 
coordination unit for project accounting and financial management. 
 
33.  Both the DOR and CAAN will establish and maintain separate project records and 
accounts to identify the financing resources received and expenditures made for the facility, 
ensuring an adequate audit trail. An independent auditor will annually audit the project accounts 
and related financial statements in accordance with international auditing standards. To further 
minimize any risks, ADB's direct payment procedure will be utilized for substantial disbursement 
of payments for works, goods, and consulting services. 
 
34.  Procurement  and  anticorruption.  The  government  has  promulgated  the  Public 
Procurement Act 2007 and Public Procurement Regulations 2007—both generally acceptable to 
ADB and encompassing best international procurement practices. These will be followed for 
national procurement of goods and works, subject to the national competitive bidding annex in 
the procurement plan. This annex documents clarifications and adjustments necessary for the 
national systems to be used on ADB-financed contracts bid for under national competitive 
bidding procedures. As mandated by the act, the Public Procurement Monitoring Office has 
been assigned as an oversight agency for public procurement in Nepal. The Public Procurement 
Monitoring  Office,16 under  the  Office  of  the  Prime  Minister  and  Council  of  Ministers,  is 
mandated, among other things, to make recommendations to the government for reform of the 
procurement policy or laws, issue technical guidelines and manuals on procurement, prepare 
standard  bidding  documents,  and  conduct  regular  training  programs  for  stakeholders.  The 
government  is  strengthening  its  effort  to  fight  corruption  and  has  enacted  legislation  with

35.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  CAAN.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual (Appendix 2). The DOR and CAAN 
will publish pertinent information relating to the facility on their websites, including business 
opportunities associated with the project, and information related to consulting services. 
 
36.  The  National  Vigilance  Centre  was  established  in  August  2002,  under  the  direct 
supervision and control of the Prime Minister of Nepal, to create awareness against corruption 
and activities related to prevent corruption. Both the DOR and CAAN will appoint auditors 
certified by the National Vigilance Centre to conduct a technical audit of the facility to examine 
how well the objectives were met within the allocated time frame and budget. Technical audits 
will be conducted during the implementation, assessing accomplishment that is mainly related to 
design quality, road safety audit implementation, schedule, and budget. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
37.  From  the  follow-on  transport  investments  prepared  under  the  proposed  facility,  the 
improved  condition  and  higher  density  of  the  road  network  will  facilitate  delivery  of  social 
services and access to shops, markets, schools, and hospitals, and help induce opportunities 
for non-agriculture employment and incomes. 
 
38.  The  facility  is  not  expected  to  have  any  physical  impact  on  gender  and  social 
dimensions. Follow-on loans and grants will be prepared in compliance with ADB's Guidelines 
for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Projects and ADB's Handbook on Social Analysis.17 
Gender, consultation and participation, labor, HIV/AIDS, and other social risks relating to follow-
on loans and grants will be assessed, and mitigation plans will be prepared to address those 
issues. 
 
39.  The facility combines project feasibility study and detailed design, and safeguard due 
diligence,  ensuring  that  (i)  follow-on  investment  projects  will  be  implemented  without 
unnecessary  delay,  and  (ii)  development  impact  of  the  follow-on  investment  projects  will 
materialize without delay. 
   
E.  Safeguards 
40.  The facility is expected to ensure development of environmentally and socially viable 
investment loans. The follow-on loans and grant will be prepared in compliance with ADB's 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and government guidelines, regulations, and policies. The 
facility is not expected to have any adverse social and environmental consequences due to the 
nature of the proposed intervention, i.e., project preparation. The safeguard categorization for 
the facility is “C” for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples, respectively. 
During the feasibility studies, the consultants will prepare environmental impact assessments or 
initial environmental examinations, including environmental management plans, for the selected 
subprojects.  Similarly,  resettlement  planning,  indigenous  peoples  planning,  and  gender 
                                                 
17  ADB. 1994. Guidelines for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Projects. Manila; ADB. 2007. Handbook on Social 
Analysis. Manila.

10 
analyses will be prepared for the selected subprojects during this stage, and will be updated 
during the detailed design stage as appropriate. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
41.  Major  risks  associated  with  implementing  the  facility  were  identified  and  practical 
mitigation measures were assessed as appropriate. To mitigate potential lack of oversight and 
guidance with respect to procurement, the Public Procurement Monitoring Office (footnote 16) 
will carry out training for project implementation unit staff of the Departments of Roads and Civil 
Aviation Authority of Nepal on technical guidelines and manuals, including refresher courses for 
the  latest  ADB  procurement  guidelines  and  standard  bidding  documents.  To  enhance 
procurement transparency, the Departments of Roads and Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal will 
disclose information about the facility and business opportunities associated with the facility on 
their websites. To help deter corruption, auditors certified by the National Vigilance Centre will 
conduct a technical audit during the implementation, assessing accomplishment that is mainly 
related to design quality, road safety audit implementation, schedule, and budget. 
 
42.  The integrated benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs. Major risks and 
mitigating measures are described in the risk assessment and risk management plan.18 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
43.  The government and CAAN have assured ADB that implementation of the facility shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
44.  The government and CAAN have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the facility, 
which are set forth in the grant agreement and project agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
45.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  grant  not 
exceeding $12,000,000 to Nepal from ADB’s Special Funds resources for the Transport Project 
Preparatory Facility, on terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft grant and project agreements presented to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
